posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked:
As of late, I have been watching numerous Behind the Bumpers videos to get more ideas of how to improve our team’s code. For the Crescendo season, our robot used the Phoenix Tuner X Swerve codebase which improved it’s smoothness a lot, but a problem we have is that our code runs entirely off of commands. This is an issue because CommandScheduler tends to only run one command at a time (from my understanding), leaving our robot’s movements kind of clunky, for lack of a better word. It also just seems kind of messy in general, because our Commands folder ends up having about 20 files and it becomes tedious to sort through all of them.

In the Behind the Bumpers videos, I hear programmers talking about states, and how a lot of stuff can be consolidated within them. I’m becoming more interested in how to implement this to our code, could anybody provide more information? Thanks in advance : )

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
There’s no short answer here; commands arguably themselves represent states.  States are an abstract concept with no single unambiguous representation in code.

We generally recommend avoiding class commands and writing commands via factory methods and capture semantics.  See the RapidReactCommandBot example project for a concrete example of this.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked:
pinkfloyd145:

CommandScheduler tends to only run one command at a time (from my understanding),

It runs one command per subsystem . Is that what you meant?

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: If you aren’t aware of the concept, I would suggest looking into the Finite State Machine (FSM).  This is a high-level concept in programming which I think could help in your research.  I learned about Finite State Machines through the facet of Game Development, and it has become very helpful to me in FRC programming.  As an example, here’s a common implementation in game dev.  When programming a player character, you very often have complicated combinations of logic.  If the player is on the ground and the jump button is pressed, then the player should jump, but if the player is touching a wall then they should wall-jump, and if the roll button is pressed when the player is on the ground but the jump button is also pressed then they player should roll but not jump, etc. etc.  The easiest way to program this logic seems to be with a long chain of boolean and if / else statements, but as you can imagine, this quickly becomes unwieldy.  Instead, you can implement a Finite State Machine by writing classes (or other abstractions depending on your language) to represent each possible state of the player.  You could make a Jumping state, a Walking state, and a Falling state.  Then you make transitions between them.  So in the Walking state, you have logic that transitions to the Jumping state if the jump button is pressed.  In the Falling state, you have logic that transitions to the Walking state if the player touches the ground.  This naturally stops invalid scenarios from occurring.  Notice that, due to the simple rules that were set up, the player will never jump when it’s not on the ground and will automatically be able to walk when it falls back onto the ground. To be honest, I’ve had struggles making FSMs work well for systems with a lot of inputs and independent logic, like an FRC robot.  As @Oblarg mentioned, Commands are kind of an implementation of FSMs (with some big changes)—I’ve had struggles with Commands too, but that’s a topic for another post.  Regardless, I still think FSM’s are a good concept to understand, and they’ve certainly helped me think of how to write better code.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
pinkfloyd145:

leaving our robot’s movements kind of clunky, for lack of a better word.

A critical concept to good code for things that move: Separating out “what” you want to do from “how” you do it.

And, for doing this smoothly - the “how” portion has to be written to accept that the “what” can change at any time.

So for example, one “what” may say “go full speed!”, then the next “what” says “stop!”.

The “how” portion might need to accept this, but limit how quickly it changes motor speeds in response to a different “what” being active.

posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked: Yeah, that’s what I meant

posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked: Honestly, that sounds like a very robust system to build a robot on, and I think it sounds fairly intuitive, having no prior knowledge of FSMs. Do you know of any teams that are actively using this type of system for their code?  Or just a general example of any Java code? Thank you!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
As mentioned, the Command scheduler is a finite state machine, so you are already using one.

Each command you write represents a possible state for one (or more) subsystems.  Trigger bindings, along with the rules of the scheduler, determine how the systems transition between these states.

posts.name: Ben Malito
posts.cooked: Oh alright, I think I understand then. Our robot is by definition using an FSM because of the Command Scheduler. Thank you for explaining that!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: No problem.  You can represent a given FSM many ways; if you want more explicit representation of states you can of course define your own (eg as enumerations).  But then you have the task of coordinating the two representations.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: It’s important to note, however, that this might not be true depending on how you are structuring your code.  As an example, this past season my team had a shooter with variable shoot speed, shoot angle, and feeder wheel speed.  We had “presets”—combinations of shoot speed, angle, and feed speed—that we had tuned to be accurate for each side of the speaker.  I decided to implement these as enumerated states within the shooter subsystem, and only have the set of possible enumerated states accessible through its public API.  Looking back, this was a bad decision, and resulted in a lot of complex and tangled state between the subsystem and its commands.  But, to this day, I’m not sure if putting all the state in the commands would really have been a better option due to the amount of data that should really be encapsulated within the subsystem. So, ideally, yes, you have all the state in the commands and they run as a FSM (or really, multiple FSMs) with the subsystems being purely tools with purely combinational logic.  But, in reality, this may not be done.  Personally, I feel like the Command-Based framework can easily be misused in a variety of ways, and needs to come with more rigid rules in order to actually be useful.  I am considering moving my team away from it and towards a more simplistic and rigid state-based system.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Paraduks:

Personally, I feel like the Command-Based framework can easily be misused in a variety of ways

This is true of any sufficiently-powerful tool; if you roll your own scheduler you will almost certainly encounter many of the same edge-cases.  You should still give it a try if you haven’t, but there’s no way around the problemspace complexity.

Paraduks:

But, to this day, I’m not sure if putting all the state in the commands would really have been a better option due to the amount of data that should really be encapsulated within the subsystem.

Commands that are tightly coupled to a particular subsystem should be defined within the scope of that subsystem; you should not be breaking encapsulation to define commands.  Factory methods and captures are your friends here.

Paraduks:

So, ideally, yes, you have all the state in the commands and they run as a FSM (or really, multiple FSMs) with the subsystems being purely tools with purely combinational logic. But, in reality, this may not be done.

Where the state lives is actually kind of orthogonal to my point, which is that no matter what you do, a Command-based robot program is some sort of FSM , because that’s how the scheduler works.  There is flexibility in how you represent your state in terms of the user code, but no matter what you do you are defining a FSM.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: What kind of behavior is what you call “clunky”? I don’t think that’s a inherent limitation of the command system.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: Finite State Machine would work even better with Command-Base

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
I’m still not convinced that putting a ton of decisions and multiple states in one command is in the true spirit of Command-Based. @Oblarg could tell me “it’s okay” but I still coach my team to try for one state per command and put the if statements in the isFinished .  (And switch etc. are problematic except in a subsystem that defines a FSM controller that really is hard to define using simpler command-based techniques). (I’m not talking about the composed group commands that use sequential and parallel to perform a complex operation.)

OP may be interested in my variety of examples I’ve put together in response to another CD thread. And Should you have State in Subsystems? (Java) - #7 by Jedi_4 has a nice example from their 2024 robot.

That post by @Jedi_4 inspired me to present a simpler example and to dust off an old FSM example. It uses command-based to create a Moore FSM of a transition being current state + Trigger → Command that is the new state. It’s in the MooreLikeFSM.java subsystem of https://github.com/tom131313/Example-LED with several examples included.

That FSM code looks complicated (bloated) only in its repetition since it has 8 states and 14 triggers that are essentially identical. It’s the Knight Rider Kitt red LED scanner. It runs in sim mode.

(Sorry I didn’t implement the time lapsed gradient fade of the scanner - that adds more bloat to the example but I still might do it when I have more time. It might be very easy since the upcoming WPILib LED routines do a lot of heavy lifting for you.) image 1126×519 45.8 KB

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: Your Example-LED repo looks private.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Sorry. I didn’t think that was possible without paying for it. My first private repository is now public thanks to Google search showing me how to.

posts.name: Amicus1
posts.cooked: You probably want to make the commands in the MooreLikeFSM command factories, as it’s bad form to bind the same instance of a command to multiple triggers and/or command groups (you’re not doing the latter but just fyi).

For use by others outside the subsystem class then certainly your recommendation of the factory is great.

Since the example was to be a self-contained FSM then below is in a more compact yet fool-proof style for Triggers since they can be instantiated (Commands cannot be instantiated like this):
